courseDescription: Interdisciplinary quantitative techniques applicable to the study of international phenomena.
Surveys major theoretical approaches to international relations and foreign policy.  A systematic introduction designed to lay a foundation for advanced graduate study.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and evaluation of international relations theories

courseTitle: American Foreign Policy and World Order
courseDescription: This course deals with the adaptation of US foreign policies to the changing structure of the international system after WWII and in the Cold War, and since Reagan.  It is designed to review, analyze, and discuss the global rise of the US role in the world.  It will also assess the transformation of US interests since 1945, through the Cold War and since the events of September 11, 2001.

Course explores how different societies in the 20th century were shaped by similar practices, ideas, and pressures.  Course themes may include colonialism, the global history of World War II, the cold war ethnic distortion and the consumer revolution among others.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating group discussions on historical themes

courseDescription: Individually arranged internship at local, state, national or international level.
The advanced study of selected (titled) topics not offered on a regular basis.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in a multicultural environment

courseDescription: The advanced study of selected topics in an interdisciplinary manner which permits small groups of qualified students to work on subjects of mutual interest.  Due to their specialized nature, seminar topics may not be offered regularly.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of specialized software for data analysis

courseDescription: Independent research on a topic from an interdisciplinary perspective.  Students must receive prior approval from the faculty supervisor and the director.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge in relevant digital research tools
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with supervisor and director
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem identification and analysis in international studies

courseDescription: Methodological and theoretical preparation designed to assist students in writing a thesis.
Writing of the thesis.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of relevant software for thesis writing

courseTitle: Global Change and American Foreign Policy
courseDescription: This research seminar examines the transformation of the U.S. role in the world in the global context of the 20th Century and since September 2001.

This seminar explores the origins of the idea of collective security, examines the attempts to organize international security collectively and assesses possibilities and opportunities for collective security arrangements after the Cold War.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of historical and current events

courseDescription: The focus of this research seminar will be on the role of normative ideas in international relations.  Students will be introduced to the growing literature on normative approaches to international relations as well as the traditional literature on the practical and philosophical problems of ethical action in the relations of states.  Although a number of policy applications will be considered, the primary focus will be on the theoretical incorporation of normative ideas into our understanding of state action in the anarchic international environment
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of international relations theories
Evaluation of ethical action in the relations of states
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Incorporating normative ideas into state action

courseDescription: This course examines Latin American politics from comparative and historical perspectives.  Particular focus is placed on various manifestations of political authority in the region and the major societal challenges to state power.  The course reviews and critiques alternative theoretical approaches to the study of state-societal relations in Latin America.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Critique and discussion of theoretical approaches
Communication of historical and comparative analysis
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Analysis and interpretation of political structures

courseDescription: An examination of the Euro-Atlantic area as a partial international system since World War II; alignments and patterns within and between the members of the European "community" and the role and attitudes of the United States and leading European states to preserve and strengthen their sovereign prerogatives and influence; and the prospects for a true Euro-Atlantic community that would link the U.S. and Europe.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of historical and contemporary political situations
Analysis of political alignments and patterns
Assessment of sovereign prerogatives and influence
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading and influencing in political contexts

courseDescription: This course covers the fundamental concepts, ideas, and approaches to the study of interdependence and transnationalism.  It seeks to expose students to the nature, role, and impact of economic, technological, strategic, and cultural interdependence.  Cases of interdependence and transnationalism are explored in the post-Cold War era.  Some focus is placed on how interdependence and transnationalism are impacting the power of the state.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of economic, technological, strategic, and cultural interdependence
Analysis of post-Cold War era cases
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and presentation of topics related to interdependence and transnationalism
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of the impact of interdependence and transnationalism on the power of the state
Identifying and understanding the nature, role, and impact of different types of interdependence
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and organizing an analysis of interdependence and transnationalism

courseDescription: This course is a graduate seminar on the domestic politics and international relations of (East) Asia focusing on both Northeast and Southeast Asia. The first half of the course examines the domestic politics of Asian countries, with a focus on mainland China, Taiwan, Japan, and South Korea. The topics include political development, state-society relations, and political economy. The second half of the course turns to foreign relations in the region, exploring various topics and different levels of analysis to understanding the regional dynamics.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Oral and written communication of complex political concepts
Discussion and debate of regional dynamics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing foreign relations and domestic politics
Understanding and analysis of regional dynamics
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on complex political topics

courseDescription: This seminar includes an advanced survey of theoretical approaches to the study of Chinese foreign policy and in-depth analyses of the domestic/international environment, ideological principles, political/economic goals, military/diplomatic instruments, decision-making processes, and global/regional consequences of Chinese foreign policy.

This seminar examines the institutions and political actors involved in global environmental policy making with emphasis on the role of the United States.  In doing so, it addresses the scientific and political debate concerning the causes, consequences, and proposed solutions of selected worldwide ecological problems, including global climate change, stratospheric ozone depletion, acid rain, and loss of biodiversity among others.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge on global climate change, stratospheric ozone depletion, acid rain, and loss of biodiversity
Grasping political and scientific debates on environmental issues
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating complex scientific and political concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing global ecological problems and their causes
Evaluating proposed solutions for environmental issues
Critical thinking in the context of global policy making
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding the role of institutions in environmental policy making
Analyzing the role of key political actors

courseDescription: A review of current literature and empirical issues concerning transnational migration and refugees.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis on migration and refugee trends
Utilization of digital resources and databases for migration studies
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interpreting and communicating complex migration issues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of migration and refugee literature
Analytical skills in understanding the causes and effects of international migration
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on migration and refugee issues

courseTitle: The New Germany in the New Europe
courseDescription: The unification of Germany and the end of the East-West conflict have changed the context within which policy is made in Europe.  What kind of Europe will emerge?  What kind of hierarchies will determine direction and pace of European politics?  The purpose of this course is to explore the role played by Germany in the development of post-Cold War European politics.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and debate on political topics
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and conducting research on post-Cold War politics

courseDescription: Analysis of the forces shaping national and transnational economic institutions and their policies on a range of contemporary issues, including North-South relations.
Technical and Digital Skills: Researching national and transnational economic institutions
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Debate and discussion of economic policies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysing the effects of economic policies

courseDescription: An introduction to the principles of international law and to the political and institutional role of law in the relations of states.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of international law cases
Analysis of political and institutional roles in relation to law
Strategic decision-making in international legal context

courseDescription: Emphasis will be placed on the transformation of French-American relations from the idyllic beginnings of the American nation to the complexities of the Cold War, to the new alignments of the new Europe and the European Union.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of political and historical documents
Use of digital libraries and archives
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating the effects of international relations

courseDescription: The fundamental goal of the course is to provide the theoretical basis for subsequent coursework and research in the comparative and regional studies track.  To achieve this goal, this seminar examines major theories and debates in comparative social and political studies based on extensive and intensive literature review.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Conducting extensive and intensive literature review

courseDescription: This seminar discusses population processes and their connections to socioeconomic development.  A nontechnical course, the goal is to introduce students to the major concerns and issues in population and current debates over the role of population in sustainable development.  It will provide students with a systematic but critical review of research findings and issues in various areas of population and development.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of population processes and socioeconomic development
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding major concerns and issues in population

courseDescription: The research seminar investigates the profound changes in international security brought about by the end of the Cold War with a specific focus on the role of nuclear weapons.  The primary purpose of the seminar is to promote research into the global aspects of the nuclear issue and to enhance understanding of the relationship between nuclear control and the New World Order.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of post-Cold War changes in security
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of international security dynamics
Analysis of the relationship between nuclear control and New World Order

courseTitle: New World Order: Chaos and Coherence
courseDescription: This course explores ideas of order and how they apply to international politics over space and time. Using theories of international relations, students look at how states and other international actors shape the principles and practices on which order is built and how these actors navigate among the many challenges and disruptions that arise. Specifically, students study the international liberal order, power shifts, and technological innovations, including cyber, and the rise and demise of norms in the international system.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of technological innovations including cyber
Understanding the principles and practices of international order
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to discuss and analyze power shifts
Capacity to understand and communicate about the rise and demise of norms in the international system
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing different international actors and their impact on order
Navigating among the challenges and disruptions that arise in international relations
Understanding and analyzing the international liberal order
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding how states and other actors shape international order
Ability to navigate the complexities of international relations
Understanding of the temporal and spatial aspects of international politics

courseDescription: An examination of the relationship between democratic politics, democratic ideals, and international relations.  Subjects covered will include trends and processes of democratization and their implications for international relations, the distinctiveness of democratic states in their international behavior, the impact of the international environment on the internal politics of democratic states, and the problems of democracy in global governance.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research on democratic trends and processes
Analysis of international behavior of democratic states
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Debating on democratic ideals and international relations
Communicating implications of democratization for international relations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis and critical evaluation of international relations
Understanding the impact of the international environment on the internal politics of democratic states
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding of democratic leadership in international relations
Organizing ideas on global governance problems

courseTitle: Advanced Statistical Techniques in International Studies
courseDescription: Introduces the use of advanced statistical techniques for the analysis of social science data.  The central objective is to give students a working understanding of multivariate analysis, with a particular focus on the techniques and problems associated with multiple regression, causal analysis, and limited dependent variable maximum likelihood models.
Technical and Digital Skills: Limited dependent variable maximum likelihood models
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem identification related to statistical analysis

courseDescription: This class focuses on core theories of international political economy, including international trade, international finance, foreign direct investment, the role of multinational corporations, and the subfield of comparative political economy. Students are introduced to the two main paradigms of contemporary economics, Keynesianism and Hayekian monetarism. Students study labor markets and industrial relations, welfare states, the domestic regulation of finance, the politics of debt, inequality, and the role of the state.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of Keynesianism and Hayekian monetarism
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Debate and discussion of economic theories
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing labor markets and industrial relations
Analyzing the domestic regulation of finance
Understanding the politics of debt and inequality
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding the role of the state in economy

courseDescription: Explores the international relations of the Middle East from World War I to the present.  Examines the origins of the Arab-Israeli and Persian Gulf Wars and their modern dimensions.  Examines the role of oil, outside powers and religion.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research online sources for historical and current events
Analyze digital media for political news and trends
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Present complex political concepts clearly and concisely
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyze historical and current events to understand political dynamics
Critical evaluation of different sources of information
Identify patterns and trends in political events

courseDescription: An analysis of France ex-colonies as they moved from colonization and decolonization to independence.  An overview of political, historical, cinematic, and literary texts with a focus on France’s relationship with its ex-colonies, and its ex-colonies’ struggles in a post-decolonized world up until contemporary times.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical reading of historical, political and literary texts
Evaluation of historical and political contexts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Synthesis of diverse sources of information

courseDescription: This class explores the complex relationships between immigration, globalization, nationalism, and media at the turn of the 21st Century. Students distinguish between different forms of migration and experiences of travel. It explores how media has depicted immigration processes and shaped public attitudes toward different immigrant groups. It also investigates how first- and second-generation immigrant populations consume and produce media that both shape and are shaped by transnational identity formations.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of media consumption and production within immigrant communities
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and articulating complex relationships between media, immigration, and globalization
Interpreting experiences of travel and migration
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Distinguishing between different forms of migration
Evaluating the impact of media on immigration processes

courseTitle: National Identity in a Global Age
courseDescription: This course will focus on narratives of national identity in the age of globalization.  Seminal works of cultural criticism, philosophy, and political philosophy will shed light on the complex nature of national identity construction in the contemporary world.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Critical discussion of cultural criticism texts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on complex topics

courseDescription: This course offers a thorough exploration into the subject of U.S. grand strategy. It confronts debates over the definition and usefulness of grand strategy, examines variations across the history of U.S. grand strategy and among current visions for U.S. grand strategy, and analyzes subjects of core concern to U.S. grand strategy.

courseTitle: International Relations of the Middle East
courseDescription: The purpose of this course is to help the student understand, evaluate and analyze key features of the international relations of the Middle East. Major issues covered include the historical background of the Middle East, primarily from World War I; Islam and Islamism; Zionism and Israel; Arab nationalism and pan-Arabism; the Arab-Israeli conflict in its historical and contemporary context; the Persian Gulf wars; global oil dynamics; the foreign policy of key regional states; the role of outside powers in the region, especially the United States; and major issues including democratization, WMD, and the Arab Spring.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of historical and contemporary conflicts
Understanding and analysis of democratization processes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding of political leadership in the Middle East context

courseDescription: The course explores on the politics of Europe, focusing on four core themes: the political economy and the travails of the single currency, the question of immigration, legitimacy and democracy, and the changing political landscape. Students will familiarize themselves with the European Union and its institutions, as well as such themes as populism, the decline of centrist political parties and economic stagnation.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research on European Union and its institutions
Analysis of political economy and single currency
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and debate on immigration issues
Communicating concepts of legitimacy and democracy
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and analysing political trends like populism and decline of centrist political parties

courseDescription: This seminar examines alternate theoretical perspectives on development.  These perspectives are then employed to understand contemporary political and economic changes in the developing world, including the consolidation of democratic governance and the liberalization of domestic economics.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Negotiation and persuasion within a political context
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of political and economic changes

courseTitle: Globalization and Social Change in the World System
courseDescription: This course is intended to first identify the distinguishing characteristics of globalization.  It then attempts to examine its implications on a number of critical issues, including the future of democracy, income distribution and ethnic, class, and gender relations.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and communicating implications of globalization
Understanding and communicating class, gender and ethnic relations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing impact of globalization on democracy
Analyzing impact of globalization on income distribution
Analyzing impact of globalization on ethnic, class, and gender relations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and documenting implications of globalization

courseDescription: Studies systems of global restructuring as they impact women throughout the globe.  Migration, international development, and transnational activism will be focal themes, explored across a variety of national contexts.

courseTitle: France's Decolonized Legacy: Africa, Asia, the Caribbean, Quebec
courseDescription: An analysis of France's ex-colonies as they moved from colonization and decolonization to independence. An overview of political, historical, cinematic, and literary texts with a focus on France's relationship with its ex-colonies, and its ex-colonies' struggles in a post-decolonized world.
Technical and Digital Skills: Critical reading of cinematic and literary texts
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding of cultural and historical contexts
Ability to interpret and communicate complex political relationships
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of political and historical developments
Critical thinking in understanding decolonization processes

courseTitle: Ethnic Conflict in the Emerging Global Order
courseDescription: Using different case studies, this course investigates the most important internal and external factors that cause ethnic conflicts. It also examines different mechanisms that help resolve or mitigate such conflicts.

courseTitle: Research Seminar in International Studies: Refugees
courseDescription: This is a graduate-level seminar focusing on the refugee movement from a global perspective.  The goals are to provide a critical and realistic understanding of the refugee phenomenon and to explain why the refugees tend to follow some identifiable paths, and why they sometimes return and sometimes do not.  Discussion will be centered on the causes and consequences of refugee flow, and the roles the more developed countries can play in helping solve the problem.
Technical and Digital Skills: Using digital platforms for global information gathering
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and interpreting international laws and policies

courseTitle: Conflict and Violence in Modern Africa
courseDescription: This course will confront the theme of conflict and violence in Africa since the mid-20th century.  It will explore the reasons behind the level of violent conflicts in the continent today, seek to understand their larger significance, and explore ideas for conflict resolution and prevention.  (cross listed with HIST 755)

courseTitle: International Cultural Studies: History, Theory and Application
courseDescription: Course analyzes culture in the context of material conditions in which it is produced, disseminated, controlled and practiced.  Theoretical application of cultural studies will include developing familiarity with key foundational theories, terminologies, and critical thinking.
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with key foundational theories and terminologies
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interpretation and dissemination of cultural context

courseDescription: Game theory uses mathematical models, empirical investigation, and simulations in an effort to explain simple and complex strategic interactions among individuals, states, groups, and species.  This course teaches the tools of game theory, with a focus on applications in international relations and political science.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Application of game theory in international relations and political science
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing interactions among individuals, states, groups, and species

courseTitle: Agent-Based Modeling and Simulation for International Studies
courseDescription: An introduction to complex systems theory and to the application of agent-based modeling technologies to a variety of social systems.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Solving problems through modeling and simulation

courseDescription: Course examines the key roles played by media technologies in implementing and promoting international development programs, as well as some of the concerns these initiatives have raised in terms of media literacy, cultural sovereignty, and information access.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the impact of media technologies on international development
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Addressing and managing concerns raised in media initiatives

courseDescription: This course introduces modeling and simulation as a tool for expanding one's understanding of events that have shaped the global environment of the 21st century. The course will first provide a broad look at international politics through a review of select international incidents, military interventions, and homeland security issues. Second, select topics from these categories will serve as case studies to facilitate representing those events with the application of modeling, simulation, and visualization. Understanding how modeling and simulation can provide another method of analysis allows students to delve deeper into their understanding of "what happened" and to explore their conception of "what if."
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussions on international incidents and military interventions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical thinking for evaluating global events
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing complex data into understandable models

courseDescription: This course explores debates in the field of Security Studies, their relevance to creating knowledge, discourse, consensus and critique, and the development of diverse research agendas.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of security studies debates

courseTitle: Seminar in Thesis and Dissertation Preparation
courseDescription: Prepares students to research, formulate and write thesis and dissertation prospectuses.
The advanced study and discussion of selected (titled) topics not offered on a regular basis.

The advanced study of selected topics in an interdisciplinary manner which will permit small groups of qualified students to work on subjects of mutual interest.  Due to their specialized nature, the course may not be offered regularly.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilization of specialized databases and resources

courseTitle: Global Change and American Foreign Policy
courseDescription: This research seminar examines the transformation of the U.S. role in the world in the global context of the 20th Century and since September 2001.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research and analysis of historical data
Use of digital tools for information gathering
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of historical events and policies
Identification and analysis of global trends
Problem-solving in the context of foreign policy

courseDescription: This seminar explores the origins of the idea of collective security, examines the attempts to organize international security collectively and assesses possibilities and opportunities for collective security arrangements after the Cold War.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the success and failures of past security arrangements
Critical evaluation of international security policies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and synthesizing complex historical and political data
Leading discussions and debates on security policies

courseDescription: The focus of this research seminar will be on the role of normative ideas in international relations.  Students will be introduced to the growing literature on normative approaches to international relations as well as the traditional literature on the practical and philosophical problems of ethical action in the relations of states.  Although a number of policy applications will be considered, the primary focus will be on the theoretical incorporation of normative ideas into our understanding of state action in the anarchic international environment
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Debate and discussion of normative ideas
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of ethical actions in international relations
Analysis of state actions in international environment
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on ethical issues in international relations

courseDescription: This course examines Latin American politics from comparative and historical perspectives.  Particular focus is placed on various manifestations of political authority in the region and the major societal challenges to state power.  The course reviews and critiques alternative theoretical approaches to the study of state-societal relations in Latin America.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and critique of theoretical approaches

courseDescription: An examination of the Euro-Atlantic area as a partial international system since World War II; alignments and patterns within and between the members of the European "community" and the role and attitudes of the United States and leading European states to preserve and strengthen their sovereign prerogatives and influence; and the prospects for a true Euro-Atlantic community that would link the U.S. and Europe.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing historical and international relations patterns
Identifying alignments within and between nations
Predicting prospects for a Euro-Atlantic community
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding of international law and sovereignty

courseDescription: This course covers the fundamental concepts, ideas, and approaches to the study of interdependence and transnationalism.  It seeks to expose students to the nature, role, and impact of economic, technological, strategic, and cultural interdependence.  Cases of interdependence and transnationalism are explored in the post-Cold War era.  Some focus is placed on how interdependence and transnationalism are impacting the power of the state.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of economic, technological, strategic, and cultural interdependence
Analysis of post-Cold War era cases of interdependence and transnationalism
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of complex concepts related to interdependence and transnationalism
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of the impact of interdependence and transnationalism on state power
Problem-solving in scenarios related to interdependence and transnationalism
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and applying theories of interdependence and transnationalism
Leadership in discussions on interdependence, power, and transnationalism

courseDescription: This course is a graduate seminar on the domestic politics and international relations of (East) Asia focusing on both Northeast and Southeast Asia. The first half of the course examines the domestic politics of Asian countries, with a focus on mainland China, Taiwan, Japan, and South Korea. The topics include political development, state-society relations, and political economy. The second half of the course turns to foreign relations in the region, exploring various topics and different levels of analysis to understanding the regional dynamics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of domestic politics and international relations of Asia
Knowledge of political development in Asian countries
Familiarity with state-society relations in Asia
Understanding of political economy in Asia
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to discuss and debate Asian politics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical skills to understand regional dynamics in Asia
Ability to critically analyse Asian politics and economy

courseDescription: This seminar includes an advanced survey of theoretical approaches to the study of Chinese foreign policy and in-depth analyses of the domestic/international environment, ideological principles, political/economic goals, military/diplomatic instruments, decision-making processes, and global/regional consequences of Chinese foreign policy.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of political and economic goals
Understanding of military and diplomatic instruments
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: In-depth discussion and debate on theories and principles
Effective communication of complex political concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of domestic and international environments
Understanding global and regional consequences of policy decisions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ability to lead and participate in group discussions

courseDescription: This seminar examines the institutions and political actors involved in global environmental policy making with emphasis on the role of the United States.  In doing so, it addresses the scientific and political debate concerning the causes, consequences, and proposed solutions of selected worldwide ecological problems, including global climate change, stratospheric ozone depletion, acid rain, and loss of biodiversity among others.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing causes and consequences of ecological problems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding the role of political actors and institutions
Navigating U.S. role in global environmental policy

courseDescription: A review of current literature and empirical issues concerning transnational migration and refugees.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and debate of empirical issues

courseTitle: The New Germany in the New Europe
courseDescription: The unification of Germany and the end of the East-West conflict have changed the context within which policy is made in Europe.  What kind of Europe will emerge?  What kind of hierarchies will determine direction and pace of European politics?  The purpose of this course is to explore the role played by Germany in the development of post-Cold War European politics.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and analyzing leadership roles in politics

courseDescription: Analysis of the forces shaping national and transnational economic institutions and their policies on a range of contemporary issues, including North-South relations.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of national and transnational economic institutions

courseDescription: An introduction to the principles of international law and to the political and institutional role of law in the relations of states.
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with political and institutional roles of law in state relations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of legal principles and their impact
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and following legal procedures in international context
Leading discussions on international law topics

courseDescription: Emphasis will be placed on the transformation of French-American relations from the idyllic beginnings of the American nation to the complexities of the Cold War, to the new alignments of the new Europe and the European Union.

The fundamental goal of the course is to provide the theoretical basis for subsequent coursework and research in the comparative and regional studies track.  To achieve this goal, this seminar examines major theories and debates in comparative social and political studies based on extensive and intensive literature review.

This seminar discusses population processes and their connections to socioeconomic development.  A nontechnical course, the goal is to introduce students to the major concerns and issues in population and current debates over the role of population in sustainable development.  It will provide students with a systematic but critical review of research findings and issues in various areas of population and development.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Engagement with current debates on sustainable development

courseDescription: The research seminar investigates the profound changes in international security brought about by the end of the Cold War with a specific focus on the role of nuclear weapons.  The primary purpose of the seminar is to promote research into the global aspects of the nuclear issue and to enhance understanding of the relationship between nuclear control and the New World Order.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis related to global security
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to discuss and explain complex global security concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of international security issues
Understanding and interpreting nuclear issues in a global context
Problem-solving in the context of global security challenges
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic planning in nuclear control and world order

courseTitle: New World Order: Chaos and Coherence
courseDescription: This course explores ideas of order and how they apply to international politics over space and time. Using theories of international relations, students look at how states and other international actors shape the principles and practices on which order is built and how these actors navigate among the many challenges and disruptions that arise. Specifically, students study the international liberal order, power shifts, and technological innovations, including cyber, and the rise and demise of norms in the international system.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Debate and discussion of international politics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of power shifts in international politics
Critical evaluation of international actors and their roles
Understanding and addressing international challenges and disruptions
Analysis of the rise and demise of norms in the international system
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and managing the principles and practices of international order

courseDescription: An examination of the relationship between democratic politics, democratic ideals, and international relations.  Subjects covered will include trends and processes of democratization and their implications for international relations, the distinctiveness of democratic states in their international behavior, the impact of the international environment on the internal politics of democratic states, and the problems of democracy in global governance.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interpreting and conveying complex political theories
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of political trends and processes
Critical evaluation of democratic ideals and their international implications
Assessment of the impact of international environment on internal politics
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and interpreting complex political data

courseTitle: Advanced Statistical Techniques in International Studies
courseDescription: Introduces the use of advanced statistical techniques for the analysis of social science data.  The central objective is to give students a working understanding of multivariate analysis, with a particular focus on the techniques and problems associated with multiple regression, causal analysis, and limited dependent variable maximum likelihood models.
Technical and Digital Skills: Working with limited dependent variable maximum likelihood models
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem identification and solving in statistical data analysis

courseDescription: This class focuses on core theories of international political economy, including international trade, international finance, foreign direct investment, the role of multinational corporations, and the subfield of comparative political economy. Students are introduced to the two main paradigms of contemporary economics, Keynesianism and Hayekian monetarism. Students study labor markets and industrial relations, welfare states, the domestic regulation of finance, the politics of debt, inequality, and the role of the state.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of foreign direct investment trends
Understanding of Keynesian and Hayekian economic paradigms
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Debate and discussion of economic theories
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of international and domestic financial policies
Evaluation of state roles in economy
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and application of economic policy
Strategic planning based on economic theories
Leadership in economic debate and discussion

courseDescription: Explores the international relations of the Middle East from World War I to the present.  Examines the origins of the Arab-Israeli and Persian Gulf Wars and their modern dimensions.  Examines the role of oil, outside powers and religion.
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with Middle Eastern religious contexts
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of complex political topics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and interpretation of geopolitical strategies

courseDescription: An analysis of France ex-colonies as they moved from colonization and decolonization to independence.  An overview of political, historical, cinematic, and literary texts with a focus on France’s relationship with its ex-colonies, and its ex-colonies’ struggles in a post-decolonized world up until contemporary times.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of literary and cinematic texts
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and debate of historical events
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of historical and political contexts

courseDescription: This class explores the complex relationships between immigration, globalization, nationalism, and media at the turn of the 21st Century. Students distinguish between different forms of migration and experiences of travel. It explores how media has depicted immigration processes and shaped public attitudes toward different immigrant groups. It also investigates how first- and second-generation immigrant populations consume and produce media that both shape and are shaped by transnational identity formations.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of media influence on public attitudes
Investigation of immigrant media consumption and production

courseTitle: National Identity in a Global Age
courseDescription: This course will focus on narratives of national identity in the age of globalization.  Seminal works of cultural criticism, philosophy, and political philosophy will shed light on the complex nature of national identity construction in the contemporary world.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interpreting and conveying complex philosophical ideas
Discussing and debating national identity concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and interpreting globalization's impact on national identity
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and summarizing complex philosophical ideas
Leading discussions on national identity and globalization

courseDescription: This course offers a thorough exploration into the subject of U.S. grand strategy. It confronts debates over the definition and usefulness of grand strategy, examines variations across the history of U.S. grand strategy and among current visions for U.S. grand strategy, and analyzes subjects of core concern to U.S. grand strategy.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and applying political science methodologies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Comparative analysis of historical and current strategies
Identifying core concerns in U.S. grand strategy

courseTitle: International Relations of the Middle East
courseDescription: The purpose of this course is to help the student understand, evaluate and analyze key features of the international relations of the Middle East. Major issues covered include the historical background of the Middle East, primarily from World War I; Islam and Islamism; Zionism and Israel; Arab nationalism and pan-Arabism; the Arab-Israeli conflict in its historical and contemporary context; the Persian Gulf wars; global oil dynamics; the foreign policy of key regional states; the role of outside powers in the region, especially the United States; and major issues including democratization, WMD, and the Arab Spring.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessing the role of outside powers in regional affairs

courseDescription: The course explores on the politics of Europe, focusing on four core themes: the political economy and the travails of the single currency, the question of immigration, legitimacy and democracy, and the changing political landscape. Students will familiarize themselves with the European Union and its institutions, as well as such themes as populism, the decline of centrist political parties and economic stagnation.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research on European Union and its institutions
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and debate of political themes
Presentation of political ideas and arguments
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of political and economic situations

courseDescription: This seminar examines alternate theoretical perspectives on development.  These perspectives are then employed to understand contemporary political and economic changes in the developing world, including the consolidation of democratic governance and the liberalization of domestic economics.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication of complex economic and political theories
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating the effects of democratic governance and economic liberalization
Applying theoretical perspectives to practical scenarios
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and managing economic and political changes

courseTitle: Globalization and Social Change in the World System
courseDescription: This course is intended to first identify the distinguishing characteristics of globalization.  It then attempts to examine its implications on a number of critical issues, including the future of democracy, income distribution and ethnic, class, and gender relations.

Studies systems of global restructuring as they impact women throughout the globe.  Migration, international development, and transnational activism will be focal themes, explored across a variety of national contexts.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of digital platforms for activism

courseTitle: France's Decolonized Legacy: Africa, Asia, the Caribbean, Quebec
courseDescription: An analysis of France's ex-colonies as they moved from colonization and decolonization to independence. An overview of political, historical, cinematic, and literary texts with a focus on France's relationship with its ex-colonies, and its ex-colonies' struggles in a post-decolonized world.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interpretation of literary and cinematic texts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and interpreting complex socio-political structures

courseTitle: Ethnic Conflict in the Emerging Global Order
courseDescription: Using different case studies, this course investigates the most important internal and external factors that cause ethnic conflicts. It also examines different mechanisms that help resolve or mitigate such conflicts.

courseTitle: Research Seminar in International Studies: Refugees
courseDescription: This is a graduate-level seminar focusing on the refugee movement from a global perspective.  The goals are to provide a critical and realistic understanding of the refugee phenomenon and to explain why the refugees tend to follow some identifiable paths, and why they sometimes return and sometimes do not.  Discussion will be centered on the causes and consequences of refugee flow, and the roles the more developed countries can play in helping solve the problem.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying underlying causes of refugee flows

courseTitle: Conflict and Violence in Modern Africa
courseDescription: This course will confront the theme of conflict and violence in Africa since the mid-20th century.  It will explore the reasons behind the level of violent conflicts in the continent today, seek to understand their larger significance, and explore ideas for conflict resolution and prevention.  (cross listed with HIST 755)
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and synthesizing large amounts of information

courseTitle: International Cultural Studies: History, Theory and Application
courseDescription: Course analyzes culture in the context of material conditions in which it is produced, disseminated, controlled and practiced.  Theoretical application of cultural studies will include developing familiarity with key foundational theories, terminologies, and critical thinking.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of key foundational theories and terminologies
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Dissemination and control of cultural information

courseDescription: Game theory uses mathematical models, empirical investigation, and simulations in an effort to explain simple and complex strategic interactions among individuals, states, groups, and species.  This course teaches the tools of game theory, with a focus on applications in international relations and political science.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying game theory to real-world scenarios
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and applying principles of international relations
Applying game theory in political science contexts

courseTitle: Agent-Based Modeling and Simulation for International Studies
courseDescription: An introduction to complex systems theory and to the application of agent-based modeling technologies to a variety of social systems.
Internship individually arranged at local, state, or international level.

Course examines the key roles played by media technologies in implementing and promoting international development programs, as well as some of the concerns these initiatives have raised in terms of media literacy, cultural sovereignty, and information access.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating the impacts of media technologies on cultural sovereignty
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Addressing concerns raised by media initiatives

courseDescription: This course introduces modeling and simulation as a tool for expanding one's understanding of events that have shaped the global environment of the 21st century. The course will first provide a broad look at international politics through a review of select international incidents, military interventions, and homeland security issues. Second, select topics from these categories will serve as case studies to facilitate representing those events with the application of modeling, simulation, and visualization. Understanding how modeling and simulation can provide another method of analysis allows students to delve deeper into their understanding of "what happened" and to explore their conception of "what if."
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to discuss select international incidents
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Conception of hypothetical scenarios ('what if' analysis)
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding of events that shape the global environment

courseDescription: This course explores debates in the field of Security Studies, their relevance to creating knowledge, discourse, consensus and critique, and the development of diverse research agendas.

courseTitle: Seminar in Thesis and Dissertation Preparation
courseDescription: Prepares students to research, formulate and write thesis and dissertation prospectuses.
The advanced study and discussion of selected (titled) topics not offered on a regular basis.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and synthesizing complex global information

courseDescription: The advanced study of selected topics in an interdisciplinary manner which will permit small groups of qualified students to work on subjects of mutual interest.  Due to their specialized nature, the course may not be offered regularly.
Independent research directed by professors.
Methodological and theoretical preparation designed to assist students in writing a dissertation.

This course is a pass/fail course for master's students in their final semester. It may be taken to fulfill the registration requirement necessary for graduation.  All master's students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour in the semester of their graduation.

This course is a pass/fail course doctoral students may take to maintain active status after successfully passing the candidacy examination.  All doctoral students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour every semester until their graduation.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and complying with academic regulations
